channel.title: All Labs Pipeline Ideas (Benetech Jira)
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

p.__text: Convert the tactile maps made by Lighthouse for the Blind in (SF) to a more convenient, mobile app (think google maps but verbally instructing blind user how to get where they want to go, that also communicates things like stairs, accessible areas, etc.)

comment.p: From Mercedes: The tactile maps they made require the use of a special Livescribe smart-pen and a corresponding braille map book. Converting it to a digital format would allow for "on the go", convenient, real time navigation with accessibility in mind for blind users.

description.p: Develop synthetic voices to sound like naturally speaking voices. I frequently hear at conferences and in our satisfaction surveys that members would like the voices to sound more natural in whatever reading tool they use for Bookshare. If you are able to achieve this cross platform, then it could also be potentially licensed to companies like Apple, etc, and bring in a revenue stream to Benetech. This is bigger picture for any accessible device that reads text, etc. to people.

p: REcharge Initiative is a non-profit organization that seeks to empower refugee women in the United States by providing them with an opportunity to build marketable technological skills and obtain employment in the Bay Area. REcharge Initiative seeks to achieve these outcomes by:
1. Hosting workshops and planned classes to teach refugee women technology skills related to fields such as web development, graphic design and data science.

2. Providing these students with nanodegree certifications, including Microsoft Office Specialization (MOS), W3Schools HTML/CSS/JS, and Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certifications, to legitimize their skills and trainings.
3. Connecting these women to employers in the Bay Area in order to ensure that they will be able to make a lasting impact in industry using the skills that they have acquired.

Our solution recognizes that refugees, especially refugee women face significant obstacles in gaining employment and assimilating and we seek to tackle this, as well as the gender imbalances in the tech industry.

item.title: [IDEA-138] Easier passwords for people with print disabilities or children

p.__text:
a. Do further research into "unconscious" data for passwords. 
 
 b. Research other alternatives to memorizing a string to add layers of protection to simple passwords, like choosing a sequence of images

item.summary: Easier passwords for people with print disabilities or children

p: Submitted on 3/6/16 via email, with additional notes from Caden: is something that has come up a few times for Bookshare and comes from the conflicting needs of users and security
We have users who are:

From the security perspective, we don't want long, complicated passwords for their own sake, we want something that is difficult to guess. For a password, the longer it is and the more symbols it can contain, the harder it is to guess. Sometimes people will refer to the harder to guess password as having "more entropy". We can offer password alternatives that provide high entropy. For example,

1. If you pay for a Coursera course, whenever you hand in an assignment, it takes your picture with a webcam, and you are required to type the same sentence, something like, "This is really my assignment blah blah blah". I'm not sure if anything intelligent happens with facial recognition on the picture, but the site claims that the timing when typing the sentence is fairly unique between users and it would clue Coursera in to a problem if someone other than the original user typed in the sentence.

2. The user could answer a number of multiple choice questions that only they know. "Which one of these pictures do you like the most"? (The problem with this is that if there are only 3 possible responses, it is easy for a hacker to guess-- far easier than guessing one of the letters of the alphabet in a password.)
3. The password could come from something the user has, like a Google Authenticator token that generates 6 digit numbers for the user to enter.

I don't think any of these answers are great, but I hope they help to describe the problem. Also, any combination can be combined to get a higher entropy equivalent to a password. (Like, short password + picture + typing a phrase.)

It may help to brainstorm solutions for one particular user problem since some of them are at odds with each other. For example, a solution involving choosing pictures might help someone who is dyslexic but that wouldn't help someone who is blind. It might also be a cool project to define a password framework, where we could plug in any of these solutions to get a desired level of entropy, and people could contribute additional password-substitute plugins to the framework.

One more thought-- I use LastPass.com to manage passwords. I enter my master password and it automatically fills in site passwords for me. How great would it be to have a password manager where the master password were one of these more-accessible alternatives, and then the password manager filled in the conventional passwords on incompatible sites for you?

li: Young children, in preschool and kindergarten
Have reading-related disabilities like dyslexia and blindness

li.__text:
Physically limited on the keyboard so that entering long strings is difficult
 For these users, memorizing a long, nonsensical password which must contain letters, numbers, and symbols, but not any dictionary words or personal information is very difficult.

description.p: Shame report website/blog for software providers and web sites who have poor accessibility. Allows people to upload stories, which may get voted up reddit or stack-overflow-style. The goal is for stories to go viral which will generate some pressure to fix the software.
Allow crowd-sourced reporting of pet stores who sell from puppy mills and which puppy mills they sell from.

description.p: Content creators want accurate, automated descriptions of complex graphics so they can provide alternative text. Create an API that accepts an image url and responds with a description. The API would engage Mechanical Turk workers to describe images.

customfieldvalue.__text:
More from the submitter: "TapTapSee does something very similar via Cloudsight API, but the responses are not oriented towards charts, graphics, and reports. 
 Using the same web workers with a more robust description framework geared towards graphics (POET with NCAM guidelines), we can provide a more accurate, automated description platform for companies to quickly describe content in bulk."

p.__text:
Support digital privacy via a free, open source tool enabling plain or encrypted document search on or offline, eliminating the need for costly cloud servers specialized in delivering search results 
. In doing so, search terms & documents are no longer vulnerable to data breaches or forced access via authorities.

customfieldvalue.__text:
More from Simon: "I have over 35 years software development experience making me an expert in algorithms. This experience put me in a position to invent an original search algorithm not requiring specialized server software to perform the search. This came from an own desire to be able to securely search larger quantities of encrypted files (e.g. GBs of emails) either online (e.g. from a cell phone) or offline without giving away / entrusting the password to a third party server; AFAIK there is currently no known technology available to do this; even ProtonMail has not found a way [2]." 
 
 [1] 
 
 [2]

description.p: expand our current training platform to provide more guidelines and interactive tools for content authors looking to make diagrams/images accessible.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: waiting to kick-off Sandisk volunteer program to complete the work started by Benetech engineering

description.p: best practice guidelines provided to/for decision-makers regarding the purchase of accessible educational materials

p: Related suggestion from Fred Slone on referral services as being part of the buy accessible program:
Thought you might find some of this of interest. (Sorry could not find the form where I am supposed to submit labs ideas)
Article talks about Dept of Ed grantees who are small businesses operating in the Ed Tech space.

EdSurge was awarded a Phase I contract that will allow it to building out its ed tech selection tool Concierge which aims to match schools' ed tech needs with appropriate vendor solutions. EdSurge will develop and test a prototype of the platform with improved capability to generate information administrators need to make decisions on selecting technology tools to drive school improvement. The prototype will also provide a venue for education technology developers to propose tools to meet school needs

Wondered if there might be a connection opportunity with the Concierge tool mentioned above and the Math Tool finder thingee Sue-Ann is working on. Would they consider broadening Concierge to accessibility tools as well? I am guessing that is not a part of Concierge at the moment. Interesting to think about getting a view into the "venue for ed tech developers proposing technology to help schools" and see what is coming

As I read through the list of awardees, I wondered if anyone of them are even considering accessibility and then think about the possibilities for those who do perhaps grow or succeed in the market, is there an opportunity? Are there trends across a series of these types of companies and products where we could offer a cross cutting accessibility solution?

description.p: automated extraction of key information from diagrams and images

p.__text:
This might be similar to 
, but with more options. In light of the recent All Children Reading/World Vision call, there seems to be a demand for an open source collection with options that not only provide alternatives in access modes (braille, audio, etc.), but also serves various needs around the world (sign language, simplified language, alternative/local language, etc.).

p: This would be like a Bookshare 2.0, supporting additional means of access (modes, language, etc.) as well as emerging types of technology (videos, media rich content, etc.). We would also link to others like ABC, IA, OER Commons, etc.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Is Learning Registry also a solution? Strategic direction for Bookshare? Need comes from the All Children Reading meeting in May 2016.

p: Idea: To help families find communities that are both walkable (environmental benefit) and have good schools (ideally public ones). If it's possible to include average cost of living, or cost to buy or rent a "typical" apartment or home, that would be a bonus. Ability to search to narrow what you are looking for etc.
I have looked for stuff that combines this type of info with no luck...
